comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Probably taken in September 1912. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E0D6123CE633A... EDISON TRAIN A SUCCESS.; Three-Car Storage Battery Demonstration to be Given To-morrow. Special to The New York Times. September 24, 1912, Tuesday WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 23. -- Successful tests of a three-car train of Edison storage battery cars were made last week on the Watchung branch of the Erie Railroad, between West Orange and Forest Hill. They have encouraged Mr. Edison to such a degree that he has arranged for a public demonstration on Wednesday in trip from the Pennsylvania Railroad Station, New York, to Long Beach.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
Thanks swanq.  That reads like a significant day in rail history.

I wonder where Edison got the rail cars?

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content:
The story says he built them at his battery factory but it seems likely he bought the cars and equipped them with his batteries. They were intended for United Railways of Cuba. I wonder if they're still in use, or sitting in a railroad museum somewhere in Cuba?

The Edison cell was one of Edison's most profitable inventions. It has several advantages over other kinds of rechargeable cells, the main one being that it lasts forever and is immune to physical and electrical abuse. In comparison, lithium cells only last three years no matter how much you use them, and just a few deep discharges or overcharges can kill a NiMH cell.

comment._content: Swang: Thanks for the source. We'll add the date "1912 Sept."
